elements.content: Primary explosives with powerful and reliable stabilities have attractive applications in the field of military and civilian technologies. In this work, four two-dimensional, solvent-free metal azide-based energetic coordination polymers [M­(N3)2(btze)] n (M = Co for 1, Cd for 2; btze = 1,2-bis­(tetrazol-1-yl)­ethane), [Cd2(N3)3Cl­(btze)2] n 3, and [Cd2(N3)2Br2­(btze)2] n 4 were prepared through a hydrothermal reaction and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. All four compounds exhibit two times higher heats of detonation than that of the traditional lead azide (LA), high thermal stabilities (>200 °C), and relatively low sensitivities. The values of enthalpies of formation (Δf H°) of 1 and 2 are high up to 4.088 and 3.925 kJ·g–1, respectively, which belong to those of the largest Δf H° values among metal-based primary explosives. Although 1 and 2 are isostructural energetic compounds, their mechanical sensitivities are discrepant, which mainly originates from different metal atomic radii and distinct levels of repulsive steric clashes between the adjacent azides. As the less sensitive ligand btze is present in place of the previously reported atrz (4,4′-azo-1,2,4-triazole), the resultant coordination polymers with the same metal center exhibit lower mechanical sensitivities confirmed by experimental results and theoretical analyses. The mechanical sensitivities of 3 and 4 with almost the same structures display similarities despite different types and amounts of halogen ions in place of azide ions. Compounds 1 and 2 are detonated with a powerful blast. The sensitivities of 1 and 2 are in the range of applicable primary explosives, which makes 1 and 2 act as competitive and safe primary explosives.

elements.content:
Introducing an insensitive, nitrogen-rich ligand in energetic coordination polymers generates safe energetic materials with reduced sensitivities.

Introduction

Primary explosives as an important component of energetic materials have been applied to initiate less sensitive and higher energetic secondary explosives. Nowadays, metal-based explosives including mercury fulminate (MF), lead styphnate (LS), and lead azide (LA) are the most extensively used primary explosives, but the Hg- and Pb-based primary explosives have high risks to the environment and health. Since the development of weapons has gone toward security and miniaturization, traditional primary explosives with high mechanical and electrostatic sensitivities and low heats of detonation have been losing their competitive edge. Many terrible accidents have been caused by primary explosives due to high sensitivities. Advancements in primary explosives have been motivated by requiring the achievement of remarkable energetic performance with relatively acceptable mechanical and electrostatic sensitivities (but not too insensitive to ignite) for the safe handling of energetic materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introducing an insensitive, nitrogen-rich ligand in energetic coordination polymers generates safe energetic materials with reduced sensitivities.

Introduction

Primary explosives as an important component of energetic materials have been applied to initiate less sensitive and higher energetic secondary explosives. Nowadays, metal-based explosives including mercury fulminate (MF), lead styphnate (LS), and lead azide (LA) are the most extensively used primary explosives, but the Hg- and Pb-based primary explosives have high risks to the environment and health. Since the development of weapons has gone toward security and miniaturization, traditional primary explosives with high mechanical and electrostatic sensitivities and low heats of detonation have been losing their competitive edge. Many terrible accidents have been caused by primary explosives due to high sensitivities. Advancements in primary explosives have been motivated by requiring the achievement of remarkable energetic performance with relatively acceptable mechanical and electrostatic sensitivities (but not too insensitive to ignite) for the safe handling of energetic materials.

elements.content: In order to obtain powerful and appropriate sensitive primary explosives, many approaches have been employed including the synthesis of energetic metal complexes, such as potassium 1,1′-dinitramino-5,5′-bistetrazolate, copper­(I) 5-nitrotetrazolate (DBX-1), and potassium 4,5-bis­(dinitromethyl)­furoxanate, and the modification of the existing primary explosives with insensitive materials, with a representative example of copper azide@carbon hybrids (MOFT-CA). In addition, another effective and straightforward route is coordination polymerization, such as [Co­(N3)2(atrz)] n (named Co-ATRZ) and [Cd­(N3)2(atrz)] n (named Cd-ATRZ) (atrz = 4,4′-azo-1,2,4-triazole) with tremendous energetic output presented recently by our group. Energetic coordination polymers (ECPs) with stable networks built by strong coordination bonds from metal centers and energetic ligands have shown promise to emerge as excellent energetic materials with favorable stabilities. By adjusting metal centers and energetic ligands, ECPs can offer tunable energetic performances.
elements.clean_text: In order to obtain powerful and appropriate sensitive primary explosives, many approaches have been employed including the synthesis of energetic metal complexes, such as potassium 1,1'-dinitramino-5,5'-bistetrazolate, copper(I) 5-nitrotetrazolate (DBX-1), and potassium 4,5-bis(dinitromethyl)furoxanate, and the modification of the existing primary explosives with insensitive materials, with a representative example of copper azide@carbon hybrids (MOFT-CA). In addition, another effective and straightforward route is coordination polymerization, such as [Co(N3)2(atrz)] n  (named Co-ATRZ) and [Cd(N3)2(atrz)] n  (named Cd-ATRZ) (atrz = 4,4'-azo-1,2,4-triazole) with tremendous energetic output presented recently by our group. Energetic coordination polymers (ECPs) with stable networks built by strong coordination bonds from metal centers and energetic ligands have shown promise to emerge as excellent energetic materials with favorable stabilities. By adjusting metal centers and energetic ligands, ECPs can offer tunable energetic performances.

elements.content: However, the research of current ECPs are still focused on the imprecise syntheses of energetic materials with multifarious structures, and the elaborative establishment of their structure–function relationship remains a great challenge. Moreover, introducing relative stable and high energy heterocycles to the sensitive metal azides to construct ECPs with structure reinforcement can be promising to obtain primary explosives with reliable stabilities. Meanwhile, energetic properties could also be tuned by the partial substitution of energetic anions by halogen anions in a fixed structure mode. Following this viewpoint, we chose the most widely investigated energetic metal azides as assembly units of ECPs and attempted to reveal the effects of metal centers, organic ligands, and anions on the energetic properties of compounds.
elements.clean_text: However, the research of current ECPs are still focused on the imprecise syntheses of energetic materials with multifarious structures, and the elaborative establishment of their structure-function relationship remains a great challenge. Moreover, introducing relative stable and high energy heterocycles to the sensitive metal azides to construct ECPs with structure reinforcement can be promising to obtain primary explosives with reliable stabilities. Meanwhile, energetic properties could also be tuned by the partial substitution of energetic anions by halogen anions in a fixed structure mode. Following this viewpoint, we chose the most widely investigated energetic metal azides as assembly units of ECPs and attempted to reveal the effects of metal centers, organic ligands, and anions on the energetic properties of compounds.

elements.content: In this study, btze-based 1 and 2 are isostructural with the reported atrz-based Co-ATRZ and Cd-ATRZ the nitrogen-rich ligand 1,2-bis­(tetrazol-1-yl)­ethane (named btze), which has almost the same molecular backbone and nearly high nitrogen content with atrz (), in constructing powerful ECPs. Furthermore, in comparison with the −NN– bonds bridging the heterocyclic rings in the ligand atrz, the −CH2–CH2– bonds bridging the heterocyclic rings in the ligand btze are more stable and have a higher degree of freedom, which implies that the btze-based ECPs may display more reliable stabilities and abundant structure types. Herein, we imported the ligand btze to the transition metal azides to acquire four 2D ECPs: [Co­(N3)2(btze)] n 1, [Cd­(N3)2(btze)] n 2, [Cd2(N3)3­Cl­(btze)2] n 3, and [Cd2(N3)2Br2­(btze)2] n 4 (). Fortunately, btze-based 1 and 2 are isostructural with the reported atrz-based Co-ATRZ and Cd-ATRZ. Thus, the simplified 2D structural model can be obtained, which can provide an effective method to reveal the relationships between the structures and energetic performances by altering metal ions and organic ligands (a,b). The Cd­(II)-based compounds 3 and 4 are isomorphic, and the effects of partially replacing azide ions with halogen ions on energetic performances were also examined (c). The energetic performances of compounds 1–4 are discussed experimentally and theoretically. The results show that btze-based 1 and 2 possess lower mechanical sensitivities than Co-ATRZ and Cd-ATRZ, and high enthalpies of formation values (4.088 and 3.925 kJ·g–1 for 1 and 2, respectively). Relatively reliable mechanical sensitivities and the high energy of 1 and 2 imply that they may serve as highly energetic and secure primary explosives.

elements.content: Sodium azide, the ligand btze, and compounds 1–4 are explosives, which might explode under certain conditions and need to be handled with standard safety precautions. Proper protective protocols (the face shield, leather coat, safety glasses, and ear plugs) must be used during processing.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Safety Precautions

Sodium azide, the ligand btze, and compounds 1-4 are explosives, which might explode under certain conditions and need to be handled with standard safety precautions. Proper protective protocols (the face shield, leather coat, safety glasses, and ear plugs) must be used during processing.

elements.content: The ligand btze was synthesized from the previous literature. All of the following chemicals were used without further purification. The elemental analyses of C, H, and N were performed on an Elementar Vario EL III microanalyzer. Powdered X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained with a Rigaku Miniflex 600 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.540598 Å) and the operating 2θ angle ranging from 5–65°. The IR data of 1–4 were collected on a PerkinElmer Spectrum using KBr disks in the range 4000–400 cm–1. Thermal stabilities were tested through a TGA/DSC Mettler Toledo thermal analyzer under the atmosphere of N2 with a heating rate of 5 K·min–1.
elements.clean_text:
Materials and Methods

The ligand btze was synthesized from the previous literature. All of the following chemicals were used without further purification. The elemental analyses of C, H, and N were performed on an Elementar Vario EL III microanalyzer. Powdered X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained with a Rigaku Miniflex 600 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.540598 Å) and the operating 2θ angle ranging from 5-65°. The IR data of 1-4 were collected on a PerkinElmer Spectrum using KBr disks in the range 4000-400 cm-1. Thermal stabilities were tested through a TGA/DSC Mettler Toledo thermal analyzer under the atmosphere of N2 with a heating rate of 5 K⋅min-1.

elements.content: In this work, in order to obtain compound 1 in a higher yield, we employed the aqueous solution in place of the DMF/H2O mixed solvent reported previously. The aqueous solution of btze (0.083 g, 0.50 mmol) in 8 mL of H2O was heated at 80 °C for 10 min, and Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.145 g, 0.50 mmol) in 3 mL aqueous solution was added. Then, NaN3 (0.065 g, 1.00 mmol) in 3 mL of aqueous solution was added. Finally, the mixtures were heated at 80 °C with vigorous stirring for 1 h, and then the resulting solution was filtered. Dark-red prism crystals were collected within 1 day. Yield: 80% (based on btze). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C4H6N14Co: C, 15.54; H, 1.96; N, 63.44. Found: C, 15.70; H, 1.82; N, 63.82. Main IR bands (KBr, cm–1): 3392 w, 3124 s, 3025 w, 2076 vs, 1516 m, 1394 vs, 1195 m, 1096 s, 1138 m, 1005 s, 889 w, 698 m, 660 w, 598 w (Figure S1, Supporting Information).

elements.content: The single-crystal XRD data were performed on Rigaku Pilatus CCD diffractometer at 293 K, which was equipped with Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data were collected by the ω-scan technique and corrected for Lp effects. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were located with theoretical calculations and refined with an isotropic vibration factor. The crystal structure of 1 was previously determined. Pertinent crystal data and structural refinement results of 2–4 are listed in . Selected bond distances and angles for 2, 3, and 4 are listed in Table S1, Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

The single-crystal XRD data were performed on Rigaku Pilatus CCD diffractometer at 293 K, which was equipped with Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data were collected by the ω-scan technique and corrected for Lp effects. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were located with theoretical calculations and refined with an isotropic vibration factor. The crystal structure of 1 was previously determined. Pertinent crystal data and structural refinement results of 2-4 are listed in . Selected bond distances and angles for 2, 3, and 4 are listed in Table S1, Supporting Information.

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. Each pair of azide ions connects two Co­(II) atoms to form a one-dimensional (1D) metal-azido chain (Figure S3, Supporting Information). Each btze ligand exhibiting a μ2-bridge mode links two Co­(II) atoms to comprise a 2D layer (a). The layers stack by interlayered van der Waals forces and the π–π interactions between tetrazole rings (3.86 Å) to produce the 3D supramolecular structure of 1 (b). The structure of 1 is similar to that of the reported Co-ATRZ.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

X-ray Crystallography

[Co(N3)2(btze)] n  1 

Compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. Each pair of azide ions connects two Co(II) atoms to form a one-dimensional (1D) metal-azido chain (Figure S3, Supporting Information). Each btze ligand exhibiting a μ2-bridge mode links two Co(II) atoms to comprise a 2D layer (a). The layers stack by interlayered van der Waals forces and the π-π interactions between tetrazole rings (3.86 Å) to produce the 3D supramolecular structure of 1 (b). The structure of 1 is similar to that of the reported Co-ATRZ.

elements.content: (a) View of the 2D layer of 1. (b) The 3D supramolecular structure of 1 with the π–π interaction between the layers.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) View of the 2D layer of 1. (b) The 3D supramolecular structure of 1 with the π-π interaction between the layers.

elements.content: Compound 2 is isomorphic with 1. Compound 2 also belongs to the triclinic space group P1̅ and features the 2D layered architecture (Figure S4, Supporting Information). The 2D layers are stacked with interlayered van der Waals forces and π–π interactions between tetrazole rings (3.68 Å) to form the 3D supramolecular structure (Figure S4c, Supporting Information). The structure of 2 is homologous with that of the reported Cd-ATRZ. Compounds 1, 2, Co-ATRZ, and Cd-ATRZ pertain to the same structural model, which provides an effective strategy for the comparison of energetic properties. Plenty of π–π interactions and strong coordination bonds can contribute to the relatively low sensitivities of 1 and 2.
elements.clean_text:
[Cd(N3)2(btze)] n  2 

Compound 2 is isomorphic with 1. Compound 2 also belongs to the triclinic space group P1̅ and features the 2D layered architecture (Figure S4, Supporting Information). The 2D layers are stacked with interlayered van der Waals forces and π-π interactions between tetrazole rings (3.68 Å) to form the 3D supramolecular structure (Figure S4c, Supporting Information). The structure of 2 is homologous with that of the reported Cd-ATRZ. Compounds 1, 2, Co-ATRZ, and Cd-ATRZ pertain to the same structural model, which provides an effective strategy for the comparison of energetic properties. Plenty of π-π interactions and strong coordination bonds can contribute to the relatively low sensitivities of 1 and 2.

elements.content: When the reaction reactant Cd­(ClO4)2­·6H2O was substituted by CdCl2, compound 3 with a new type of structure was generated, which crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pna21. The asymmetric unit comprises two crystallographically independent Cd­(II) atoms, two btze ligands, one chloride ion, and three azide anions (). The two independent Cd­(II) atoms are both six coordinated to produce distorted octahedral geometries. The Cd1 atom forms the equatorial bonds with two btze ligands (Cd1–N11, 2.398(6) Å; Cd1–N21, 2.410(6) Å) and two μ1,1-azido anions (Cd1–N4, 2.330(6) Å; Cd1–N7, 2.340(6) Å), while the axial bonds consist of one μ1,1-azido anion (Cd1–N1, 2.356(7) Å) and one μ2-chloride anion (Cd1–Cl1, 2.598(6) Å). The equatorial bonds of the Cd2 coordination polyhedron are occupied by the four nitrogen atoms from three μ1,1-azido anions (Cd2–N4, 2.316(6) Å; Cd2–N1A 2.343(7) Å; Cd2–N7A, 2.313(6) Å) and one btze ligand with the N18F atom and Cl1 anion located at the axial position. The adjacent Cd­(II) centers are alternately connected by two μ1,1-azido anions, and one chloride anion and one μ1,1-azido anion to generate an infinite 1-D zigzag chain with a Cd­(II)···Cd­(II) distance of 3.6137(1) and 3.6855(1) Å, respectively (a). Then, the adjacent chains are joined by btze ligands, exhibiting μ2-κN11: κN18 and μ2-κN21: κN27 coordination styles, respectively, to form a 2D layer parallel to the ab plane (b). These layers are stacked in an −ABAB– sequence along the c-direction via van der Waals forces to produce the 3D supramolecular architecture (c and Figure S7, Supporting Information).

elements.content: Compound 4 is almost isostructural with 3 ( and ) and also crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pna21. Two μ2-bromine anions in the asymmetric unit of 4 are in place of one μ2-chloride anion and one μ1,1-azido anion in 3. Similar to 3, each of the two independent Cd­(II) atoms in 4 is hexacoordinated to construct an octahedral geometry. These bonds lengths of Cd1–N1, Cd1–N4, Cd1–N27D, and Cd1–Br1 in the equatorial plane lie between 2.269(12) and 2.6921(18) Å, while the Cd1–N17C and Cd1–Br2B bonds lengths located at the apical positions are 2.451(13) and 2.803(2) Å, respectively. For the Cd2 atom, N1, N4, N11, and Br2 constitute the equatorial plane, and N21 and Br1A atoms occupy the axial positions with Cd2–Br/N bond lengths in the range of 2.203(12)–2.748(2) Å. Each pair of μ2-bromine anions and μ1,1-azido anions connects the neighboring Cd­(II) centers to form a 1D zigzag chain (a). Furthermore, the btze ligands link the surrounding 1D chains to produce a 2D layered structure (b).

elements.content: The thermal behaviors of 1–4 are shown in TGA–DSC curves in . Sharp exothermic peaks emerged at 253 °C for 1, 212 °C for 2, 220 °C for 3, and 216 °C for 4, indicating rapid decomposition of the four ECPs, which can exact correspond to TGA curves with a mass of weight loss around the sharp exothermic peak. The powerful explosions occurred in 1, 2, and 3, which are deduced from the overweight observed in the TGA curves. The thermal stabilities of the four energetic materials all exceed 200 °C, which can meet the fundamental criteria for practice.

elements.content: The four compounds have high nitrogen contents (63.44% for 1, 54.07% for 2, 48.72% for 3, and 38.47% for 4) with plenty of energetic NN, N–N, and C–N bonds, which may be expected to function as energetic materials. To obtain enthalpies of formation (Δf H°) of 1–4, the constant-volume combustion heats (Δc U) values are determined to be 12.736, 11.377, 10.310, and 9.066 kJ·g–1, respectively (details in the Supporting Information). The Δf H° values of 1–4 calculated by the Hess law are 4.088, 3.925, 2.862, and 2.587 kJ·g–1, respectively (details in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: The heat of detonation (ΔH det) is one of the most crucial properties for the application of energetic materials. In order to gain the relatively accurate ΔH det, we selected the approach developed by Pang to calculate the ΔH det values, which has been widely applied to obtain the ΔH det values of metal-based explosives. The calculated ΔH det for 1, 2, 3, and 4 are 4.39, 4.18, 3.39, and 3.16 kJ·g–1, respectively, on the basis of with the above obtained Δf H° of explosives and the known Δf H° of the corresponding denotation products (details in the Supporting Information). elements.content: Because the EXPLO5 software cannot tolerate the elements such as Co and Cd, we are unable obtain the detonation velocity (D) and detonation pressure (P) of 1–4 using EXPLO5 software. Herein, we employ the modified Kamlet–Jacbos equations to calculate the D and P values (details in the Supporting Information), which have been authenticated that calculation data can exhibit good accuracy compared with those based on the EXPLO5 software. The calculated D values were determined to be 7.339 km·s–1 for 1, 7.088 km·s–1 for 2, 6.476 km·s–1 for 3, and 6.119 m·s–1 for 4. The values of P of 1, 2, 3, and 4 were calculated to be 25.03, 24.37, 20.49, and 19.25 GPa, respectively.

elements.content: The sensitivities are another significant indicator to evaluate the safety of energetic materials, which was classified on the basis of the U.N. Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods (for experimental details see the Supporting Information). Compounds 1, 2, 3, and 4 and other primary explosives are selected for comparison as displayed in and . The impact sensitivity (IS) of 1, 2, 3, 4, and btze is determined to be 1.5, 1.8, 2.0, 2.0, and >40 J, respectively, and the friction sensitivity (FS) values of 1, 2, 3, 4, and btze are 48, 80, 360, 360, and 360 N, respectively. The IS values of 1–4 are comparable to that of LA (IS = 2.5 J) (b), while the FS values of 1–4 show certain advantages over that of LA (FS = 0.5 N) as shown in c. The electrostatic discharge (ESD) values of 1, 2, 3, and 4 are measured to be 27.94, 29.81, 20.20, and 17.82 mJ, respectively. Compared with the reported primary explosives and the commercial primary explosives LA and LS, the four compounds with relatively low ESD values are much safer (d). It is worth mentioning that violent explosions were observed during the ESD tests for 1 and 2 (). These results demonstrate that both 1 and 2 are promising materials for primary explosives.

elements.content: The mechanical sensitivities of energetic materials are greatly affected by the intramolecular interactions. The noncovalent interactions (NCI) plots were determined by the calculation based on the approach by Yang (). This method can provide the detection of the differences between repulsive steric clashes, van der Waals interactions, and hydrogen bonds by analysis of the relationship between the reduced density gradient (s = 1/2­(3π2)1/3)|∇ρ|/ρ4/3) and quantum-mechanical electron density (ρ). Because of this theory, we can observed that in contrast with 2, the NCI domains of the nonbonded overlap of 1 are larger (a,b), which can be interpreted from the structural analyses with the distinct average distances of adjacent N3 – of ca. 3.28 Å for 2 and 3.01 Å for 1 (c,d). The discrepant radii of Co­(II) of 1 and Cd­(II) of 2 result in the different distances of neighboring N3 – in 1 and 2. In spite of the isostructuralism of 1 and 2, compound 1 is easier to ignite because of the stronger repulsive steric clashes in the azides. Additionally, in consideration of the distinct electronic configurations from the metal centers, the Co2+ ion with the unpaired 3d electrons probably renders 1 more sensitive than 2 with the 3d10 configuration in the Cd2+ ion. Compounds 1 and 2 represent another instance that metal centers exert obvious effects on the sensitivity of ECPs.
elements.clean_text:
Effects of Metal Centers and Organic Ligands on Mechanical Sensitivities

The mechanical sensitivities of energetic materials are greatly affected by the intramolecular interactions. The noncovalent interactions (NCI) plots were determined by the calculation based on the approach by Yang (). This method can provide the detection of the differences between repulsive steric clashes, van der Waals interactions, and hydrogen bonds by analysis of the relationship between the reduced density gradient (s = 1/2(3π2)1/3)|∇ρ|/ρ4/3) and quantum-mechanical electron density (ρ). Because of this theory, we can observed that in contrast with 2, the NCI domains of the nonbonded overlap of 1 are larger (a,b), which can be interpreted from the structural analyses with the distinct average distances of adjacent N3 - of ca. 3.28 Å for 2 and 3.01 Å for 1 (c,d). The discrepant radii of Co(II) of 1 and Cd(II) of 2 result in the different distances of neighboring N3 - in 1 and 2. In spite of the isostructuralism of 1 and 2, compound 1 is easier to ignite because of the stronger repulsive steric clashes in the azides. Additionally, in consideration of the distinct electronic configurations from the metal centers, the Co2+ ion with the unpaired 3d electrons probably renders 1 more sensitive than 2 with the 3d10 configuration in the Cd2+ ion. Compounds 1 and 2 represent another instance that metal centers exert obvious effects on the sensitivity of ECPs.

elements.content: Now we turn our attention to the influence of organic ligands on the sensitivity of four isostructural compounds 1, 2, Co-ATRZ, and Cd-ATRZ. For convenience of discussion, compounds 1 and 2 are also named as Co-BTZE and Cd-BTZE, respectively. The mechanical sensitivities of Co-BTZE 1 (FS = 48 N and IS = 1.5 J) are more stable than Co-ATRZ (FS = 5 N and IS = 1.2 J). Meanwhile, Co-BTZE 2 (FS = 80 N and IS = 1.8 J) are also securer than Cd-ATRZ (FS = 12 N and IS = 1.6 J). When the organic ligand transforms from atrz to less sensitive btze with the same metal centers and molecular frameworks, the mechanical sensitivities of the corresponding compounds with the same metal coordination centers are decreased ().

To elucidate the effects of organic ligands on the sensitivities, we established a structural sketch map based on the molecular frameworks of isomorphic Co-BTZE 1, Co-ATRZ, Cd-BTZE 2, and Cd-ATRZ (). The explosion process of the energetic materials by the external mechanical action mainly follow several steps as illustrated in Figure S11 (in the Supporting Information). Because of the similar structure in Co-BTZE 1, Co-ATRZ, Cd-BTZE 2, and Cd-ATRZ, the explosion mechanism based on the destruction of the crystal shape of the four compounds is almost identical. When the external mechanical stimuli applied to the energetic materials, the crystal shape of energetic materials would be changed by horizontal sliding and vertical compression (b). As the horizontal sliding would initiate the organic ligand, the −NN– bond in atrz will be more easily activated in contrast with the −CH2–CH2– bond in btze, which may allow the btze-based compounds to absorb more external mechanical energy than the ligand atrz-based ones (c). In fact, the sensitivity test results show that the mechanical sensitivity of Co-ATRZ is higher than that of Co-BTZE 1, and Cd-ATRZ is also more sensitive than Cd-BTZE 2. Similarly, Cd-BTZE 2 displays high mechanical stability compared with Cd-ATRZ.

The explosion process of the energetic materials by the external mechanical action mainly follow several steps as illustrated in Figure S11 (in the Supporting Information). Because of the similar structure in Co-BTZE 1, Co-ATRZ, Cd-BTZE 2, and Cd-ATRZ, the explosion mechanism based on the destruction of the crystal shape of the four compounds is almost identical. When the external mechanical stimuli applied to the energetic materials, the crystal shape of energetic materials would be changed by horizontal sliding and vertical compression (b). As the horizontal sliding would initiate the organic ligand, the -NN- bond in atrz will be more easily activated in contrast with the -CH2-CH2- bond in btze, which may allow the btze-based compounds to absorb more external mechanical energy than the ligand atrz-based ones (c). In fact, the sensitivity test results show that the mechanical sensitivity of Co-ATRZ is higher than that of Co-BTZE 1, and Cd-ATRZ is also more sensitive than Cd-BTZE 2. Similarly, Cd-BTZE 2 displays high mechanical stability compared with Cd-ATRZ.

elements.content: In summary, the nitrogen-rich ligand 1,2-bis­(tetrazol-1-yl)­ethane (btze) has successfully been incorporated into metal azides to produce four 2D energetic coordination polymers [M­(N3)2(btze)] n (M = Co 1, Cd 2), [Cd2(N3)3­Cl­(btze)2] n 3, and [Cd2(N3)2Br2(btze)2] n 4, which have been structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The btze-based 1 and 2 and the previously reported atrz-based Co-ATRZ and Cd-ATRZ are isostructural. Partially substituting azide ions with halogen ions in 2 yielded the Cd­(II)-based isomorphic 3 and 4. The energetic performances of 1–4 were investigated experimentally and theoretically. On the basis of highly similar 2D networks, the relationships between molecular structures and energetic properties have been elucidated. The enthalpies of formation (Δf H°) values of btze-based 1 and 2 are high up to 4.088 and 3.925 kJ·g–1, respectively, which are comparable with that of Co-ATRZ with the largest Δf H° in the metal-based primary explosives. The heat of detonation (ΔH det) values of 1, 2, 3, and 4 are superior than that of the commercially used lead azide (LA). Meanwhile, the stabilities of four compounds are relatively reliable with the low friction and electrostatic sensitivities in contrast with LA. With the decrease of the nitrogen content of compounds 1 to 4, Δf H°, ΔH det, the detonation velocity (D), and detonation pressure (P) from 1 to 4 present a descending trend. The noncovalent interaction calculations show greater repulsive steric clashes between the azides in the Co­(II) polymer 1 than those in the Cd­(II) polymer 2, which makes 1 more sensitive than 2. The introduction of less sensitive btze makes 1 more mechanically stable than Co-ATRZ, and 2 more mechanically stable than Cd-ATRZ. Different mechanical stabilities of isomorphic 1, 2, Co-ATRZ, and Cd-ATRZ have also been discussed based on the molecular structures. The [Cd­(μ2-N3)2Cd] dinuclear units play a vital role in the mechanical sensitivities of 3 and 4. The appropriate mechanical sensitivities and powerful performances indicate that 1 and 2 can meet the basic requirements for practical application and act as competitive candidate materials for primary explosives. This work offers coordination polymerization as an effective method to reasonably design powerful and safe primary explosives with tunable energetic properties by adjusting metal centers and organic ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, the nitrogen-rich ligand 1,2-bis(tetrazol-1-yl)ethane (btze) has successfully been incorporated into metal azides to produce four 2D energetic coordination polymers [M(N3)2(btze)] n  (M = Co 1, Cd 2), [Cd2(N3)3Cl(btze)2] n  3, and [Cd2(N3)2Br2(btze)2] n  4, which have been structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The btze-based 1 and 2 and the previously reported atrz-based Co-ATRZ and Cd-ATRZ are isostructural. Partially substituting azide ions with halogen ions in 2 yielded the Cd(II)-based isomorphic 3 and 4. The energetic performances of 1-4 were investigated experimentally and theoretically. On the basis of highly similar 2D networks, the relationships between molecular structures and energetic properties have been elucidated. The enthalpies of formation (Δf H°) values of btze-based 1 and 2 are high up to 4.088 and 3.925 kJ⋅g-1, respectively, which are comparable with that of Co-ATRZ with the largest Δf H° in the metal-based primary explosives. The heat of detonation (ΔH det) values of 1, 2, 3, and 4 are superior than that of the commercially used lead azide (LA). Meanwhile, the stabilities of four compounds are relatively reliable with the low friction and electrostatic sensitivities in contrast with LA. With the decrease of the nitrogen content of compounds 1 to 4, Δf H°, ΔH det, the detonation velocity (D), and detonation pressure (P) from 1 to 4 present a descending trend. The noncovalent interaction calculations show greater repulsive steric clashes between the azides in the Co(II) polymer 1 than those in the Cd(II) polymer 2, which makes 1 more sensitive than 2. The introduction of less sensitive btze makes 1 more mechanically stable than Co-ATRZ, and 2 more mechanically stable than Cd-ATRZ. Different mechanical stabilities of isomorphic 1, 2, Co-ATRZ, and Cd-ATRZ have also been discussed based on the molecular structures. The [Cd(μ2-N3)2Cd] dinuclear units play a vital role in the mechanical sensitivities of 3 and 4. The appropriate mechanical sensitivities and powerful performances indicate that 1 and 2 can meet the basic requirements for practical application and act as competitive candidate materials for primary explosives. This work offers coordination polymerization as an effective method to reasonably design powerful and safe primary explosives with tunable energetic properties by adjusting metal centers and organic ligands.

cln_elements.content:
In this work, in order to obtain compound 1 in a higher yield, we employed the aqueous solution in place of the DMF/H2O mixed solvent reported previously. The aqueous solution of btze (0.083 g, 0.50 mmol) in 8 mL of H2O was heated at 80 °C for 10 min, and Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.145 g, 0.50 mmol) in 3 mL aqueous solution was added. Then, NaN3 (0.065 g, 1.00 mmol) in 3 mL of aqueous solution was added. Finally, the mixtures were heated at 80 °C with vigorous stirring for 1 h, and then the resulting solution was filtered. Dark-red prism crystals were collected within 1 day. Yield: 80% (based on btze). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C4H6N14Co: C, 15.54; H, 1.96; N, 63.44. Found: C, 15.70; H, 1.82; N, 63.82. Main IR bands (KBr, cm–1): 3392 w, 3124 s, 3025 w, 2076 vs, 1516 m, 1394 vs, 1195 m, 1096 s, 1138 m, 1005 s, 889 w, 698 m, 660 w, 598 w (Figure S1, Supporting Information).

Syntheses of [Cd­(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(btze)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> <bold>2</bold>

The procedure was similar to 1 except that Co­(NO3)2·6H2O was used in place of Cd­(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.210 g, 0.50 mmol). Yield: 70% (based on btze). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C4H6N14Cd: C, 13.24; H, 1.65; N, 54.07. Found: C, 13.43; H, 1.61; N, 54.04. Main IR bands (KBr, cm–1): 3126 s, 2072 vs, 1492 m, 1453 w, 1338 w, 1176 s, 1138 m, 1090 s, 983 s, 867 m, 690 s, 652 s (Figure S1, Supporting Information).

Syntheses of [Cd<sub>2</sub>(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub>Cl­(btze)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> <bold>3</bold>

The procedure was similar to 1 except that Co­(NO3)2·6H2O was used in place of CdCl2 (0.092 g, 0.500 mmol). Yield: 65% (based on btze). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C8H12N25ClCd2: C, 13.37; H, 1.68; N, 48.72. Found: C, 13.58; H, 1.73; N, 48.38. Main IR bands (KBr, cm–1): 3143 m, 3017 m, 2071 vs, 1495 s, 1442 m, 1347 s, 1285 m, 1177 s, 1096 s, 985 m, 866 m, 660 s, 498 w (Figure S1, Supporting Information).

Syntheses of [Cd<sub>2</sub>(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>­Br<sub>2</sub>(btze)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> <bold>4</bold>

The procedure was similar to 1 except that Co­(NO3)2·6H2O was used in place of CdBr2·4H2O (0.172 g, 0.500 mmol). Yield: 66% (based on btze). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C8H12N22Br2Cd2: C, 12.00; H, 1.51; N, 38.47. Found: C, 12.33; H, 1.68; N, 38.20. Main IR bands (KBr, cm–1): 3381 w, 3134 s, 3011 m, 2071 vs, 1484 s, 1430 s, 1330 s, 1291 s, 1176 s, 1198 s, 983 s, 868 s, 660 s, 598 w, 497 w (Figure S1, Supporting Information). The four compounds 1–4 were washed thoroughly using ethanol and distilled water ultrasonic before measurement. The peak positions of the simulated and experimental PXRD patterns are in accordance with each other, indicating the pure phases of the as-synthesized compounds 1–4 (Figure S2, Supporting Information).

cln_elements.content:
The thermal behaviors of 1–4 are shown in TGA–DSC curves in . Sharp exothermic peaks emerged at 253 °C for 1, 212 °C for 2, 220 °C for 3, and 216 °C for 4, indicating rapid decomposition of the four ECPs, which can exact correspond to TGA curves with a mass of weight loss around the sharp exothermic peak. The powerful explosions occurred in 1, 2, and 3, which are deduced from the overweight observed in the TGA curves. The thermal stabilities of the four energetic materials all exceed 200 °C, which can meet the fundamental criteria for practice.

Energetic Properties

The four compounds have high nitrogen contents (63.44% for 1, 54.07% for 2, 48.72% for 3, and 38.47% for 4) with plenty of energetic NN, N–N, and C–N bonds, which may be expected to function as energetic materials. To obtain enthalpies of formation (Δf H°) of 1–4, the constant-volume combustion heats (Δc U) values are determined to be 12.736, 11.377, 10.310, and 9.066 kJ·g–1, respectively (details in the Supporting Information). The Δf H° values of 1–4 calculated by the Hess law are 4.088, 3.925, 2.862, and 2.587 kJ·g–1, respectively (details in the Supporting Information).
